action.action-desc: Mr. McCaul (for himself, Mr. Allen, Mr. Roe of Tennessee, Mr. Brat, and Mr. Gohmert) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committee on the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To require each agency to repeal or revise 1 or more existing regulations before issuing a new regulation, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the One In, One Out Act.

section.header: Repeal or revision of regulations required before issuance of a new rule

paragraph.text: the terms agency and rule have the meanings given those terms in section 551 of title 5, United States Code; and
the term State means each of the several States, the District of Columbia, each territory or possession of the United States, and each federally recognized Indian tribe.

subsection.text: An agency may not issue a rule unless the agency has repealed or revised in a way that reduces costs to the regulated entities 1 or more rules described in subsection (e) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the rule.

paragraph.text: An agency may not issue a rule unless—

subparagraph.text: the agency has repealed 1 or more rules described in subsection (e) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the rule; and
the cost of the new rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed or revised.

paragraph.text: For any rule subject to paragraph (1), the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs of the Office of Management and Budget shall certify, before the rule is issued, that the cost of the new rule is equal to or less than the cost of the rules repealed or revised.

subsection.text: Any rule repealed or revised under subsection (b) or (c) shall be published in the Federal Register.

paragraph.text: applies to any rule that imposes a cost or responsibility on a nongovernmental person or a State or local government; and
shall not apply to any rule—

subparagraph.text: that relates to procurement by the agency; or
that is being revised to be less burdensome to decrease requirements imposed by the rule or cost of compliance.
